ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book Hiking Day. We saw how the girl and her parents got ready for their hike up Hickory Hill. The girl put on her sneakers so that her feet would be comfortable. Then, she put on her hat to help keep the sun out of her eyes. And then she filled her water bottle so that she would not be thirsty on the hike. She wanted to have everything ready.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Explain the Activity In this activity, we will look at pictures of different people getting ready to start different activities. We will look at the pictures and guess the activity the person is about to do.
Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.
Talk About Getting Ready for School Ask children to talk about how they get ready for school every day. What do they do first? Let’s talk about what you do after you get up.

Ask children to describe what they see in the pictures. Ask them to talk about the person, then talk about what the person is doing. Ask, Does the person have anything in their hands or on their head? How are they dressed? Where are they?

Ask children to come up with other scenarios for what the people in the pictures are about to do. For example, the first picture could be of the child going to school, or it could be of the child coming home from school.

Children may want to use words or phrases in their home language as they describe what they do to get ready for school in the morning. Provide them with help, including translating any of their sentences into English where necessary.

While there will be a range of “normal,” children’s speech at age three should be understood by a stranger about 75% of the time, at age four 75–95% of the time, and at age five 95% of the time. Provide safe opportunities for children to express themselves and use oral language. For many children, repetition can be a non-threatening way to practice using complete sentences.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Hiking Day and we learned about how the girl and her parents worked together to plan their hike up Hickory Hill. We saw how they reached the top together. We learned that we can do many things better if we do them together. When we work together toward a goal, we work together to get something done.
When we talk and share, we talk about things we do or like to do, and we share how we do them. Today we will talk and share about different ways that we can work together.
Today we will look at pictures of people working together. We’ll say what’s happening in each picture. Then we will talk about how we can work together.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About Working Together with Friends Ask children to talk about how much easier it is to work together with someone. Have children discuss what they like about working together with their friends.
Talk About Working Together with Family Ask children to give examples of ways that they work or play together with their family.

If children respond with a phrase, have them repeat a complete sentence after you. If children, for example, say, “plant a tree,” respond, “Very good! They are planting a tree together. Can you say that after me?”

Encourage children to participate in peer-to-peer conversations about the activity they see in each picture. Remind children that while one person is talking, the other is listening. The talker should hold the card as a reminder of this.

When talking about activities, take time to model language patterns—for example, Do you like to work together? and What do you like about working together? Helping children learn to recognize language patterns will support their exponential language growth.

Encourage a conversation about the different ways they can work together with friends. One conversation strategy is to restate what a child has said and then immediately ask: Is that what you meant? By restating what a child has said, you validate their contributions, make sure that you understood the child correctly, and model correct language. Children will listen more closely to their classmates if they know that you may ask for volunteers to restate what the classmate just said.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book Hiking Day. The girl and her parents went on a hike up Hickory Hill. On their way through the woods, they saw different animals.
We learned the word woods. Let’s revisit that word since it has something to do with today’s activity.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of animals you can see in the woods. Then we will say if the animal in the picture is one of the animals the family saw on their hike.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Hand Signals Ask children to give a thumbs-up if the picture shows an animal the family saw or a thumbs-down if it does not show an animals the family saw. Model.
Ask Show the next picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About Animals in the Woods Invite children to think about all of the animals they saw on the picture cards. Encourage them to name other animals. They can start by naming the other animals the family encountered on their hike: the chipmunk and the deer.

Show children three picture cards at a time, where one is an example of an animal that the family saw and the other two are not (e.g., the toad, the porcupine, and the bear). Ask: Which one doesn’t belong? Then ask: How do you know? Repeat with other groups of three cards.

Display all six picture cards. Ask children what they know about each of the animals. Encourage children to use as much detail as possible. They can describe what the animal looks like or where the animals lives.
Invite children who speak a language other than English to teach the rest of the class the names for different animals in the other language, if they know them.
Research shows that multilingual learners are often more adept at flexible thinking, as they come to learn at any early age that a given object can have different names in different languages.

Provide immediate incentives for positive behavior. Provide stickers, for example, when a child meets a clearly defined behavioral goal, spends time working at a particular task, or demonstrates a particular Mind Builder skill such as talking and sharing or trying a new approach or a new task.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read We Have Soup! and we saw that the rabbits in the story had grown vegetables in their gardens. But when the winter came, they had to live on only one vegetable all winter long—for breakfast, lunch, and dinner!
In this activity, we will look at pictures of different vegetables, talk about how they grow, and sort them into two groups:

section-block.ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted: Above Ground: Vegetables that grow above the ground
Below Ground: Vegetables that grow under the ground
section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Hand Signals Ask children to give a thumbs-up if the picture shows a vegetable that grows above ground or a thumbs-down for vegetables that grow below ground. Model.
Ask Show the next picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Sort Give the picture card to a child to place in the “above ground” or “below ground” group.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.
Talk About Seasons Discuss with children the growing season and how people plant seeds in the spring and harvest their crops in the fall.

Ask Have students discuss why the father in Hiking Day said “Getting ready for winter” when he saw the chipmunk with a nut in her mouth. Explain that animals like chipmunks, beavers, and mice collect food in the fall to prepare for the winter.
Check children’s understanding of above ground and below ground before you begin. You might want to model the words by asking children to place different objects above or below a table or a chair.

Ask children to describe each vegetable. What color is it? What does it feel like? How do you prepare it? Does it have an outer skin that you need to cut off or peel? Does it have a leafy top? How does it taste?

The foods we eat form a big part of our cultural heritage. There are differences across cultures in ingredients, preparation, and preservation of foods. Different cultures eat different foods for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Showing an interest in and appreciation for the foods that a child eats at home is a way of valuing that child’s culture. Arrange an International Day or Pot Luck where families can bring their favorite dishes to share with the class. Show your personal appreciation for each food by tasting each food and showing that you think it’s tasty. Your children will notice.
Bring in examples of sweet and sour fruits, such as pineapples, lemons, mangoes, grapefruits, and oranges. Ask children to smell and taste the different fruits and describe the smell and taste.
